body:
Hey, sorry it came off that way.

> It makes me feel that since I'm not a google employee I wouldn't have an idea that could be worth the consideration of google employees.

It has nothing to do with google employees vs non-google employees, but rather the scope and purpose of the proposed change. To be considered seriously at this late stage of the language's development, the change must solve a real, significant problem or it must beÂ very minor indeed. Take a look at the [change history of the spec](https://github.com/golang/go/commits/master/doc/go_spec.html) to get an idea of what passes for 'language change' over the last few years. (Almost all the changes there do not affect users of the language at all.)
